text: AGENDA ITEM #10
label: HH1

text: March 11, 2005
label: TITLE

text: To:
label: BODY

text: Delta Protection Commission
label: BODY

text: From:
label: BODY

text: Margit Aramburu, Executive Director
label: BODY

text: Subject:
label: BODY

text: Discussion of Possible of Joint Adoption of Joint Resolution with the City
label: BODY

text: of Elk Grove Regarding Inclusion of Lands in the Delta Primary Zone in
label: BODY

text: the "Planning Area" within the City 's General Plan
label: BODY

text: (For Commission Discussion and Possible Action)
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATION:
label: HH1

text: Review and discuss the attached draft Joint Resolution, and determine if the draft Joint
label: BODY

text: Resolution addressees the concerns of the Commission raised at the May 2004 meeting.
label: BODY

text: If yes, vote to direct the Chairman to sign on behalf of the Commission.  If not, direct
label: BODY

text: staff to respond with alternative language or actions.
label: BODY

text: BACKGROUND:
label: HH1

text: At its meeting in May 2004, the Commission discussed the City of Elk Grove's newly
label: BODY

text: adopted General Plan.  The City's General Plan includes lands in the Primary Zone of the
label: BODY

text: Delta that are labeled "Planning Area". The General Plan notes that the City has no
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction over lands outside the City Limits and that any discussion of such lands are
label: BODY

text: purely advisory.
label: BODY

text: At the May meeting, there was considerable discussion of the role of cities in the Primary
label: BODY

text: Zone, and the role of the City of Elk Grove in the Primary Zone (see attached minutes).
label: BODY

text: The Chairman directed staff to send a letter to the City requesting a meeting to discuss
label: BODY

text: the issues raised at the Commission meeting.
label: BODY

text: Highlights from the minutes include:
label: BODY

text: • Concerns that the City's Planning Area overlaps the boundaries of the Cosumnes
label: BODY

text: Preserve.
label: BODY

text: • Concerns that the City's Planning Area overlaps the boundaries of the Stone Lakes
label: BODY

text: National Wildlife Refuge.
label: BODY

text: • Suggestion that the City delete from the General Plan any lands in the Primary Zone
label: BODY

text: of the Delta, and that I-5 serve as the western boundary of the City and the City's
label: BODY

text: General Plan.
label: BODY

text: • Suggestions that the City clarify to the Commission the issues/concerns/possible
label: BODY

text: future land uses for the lands in the Planning Area in the Primary Zone of the Delta.
label: BODY

text: • Concerns that other cities would designate portions of the Primary Zone as Planning
label: BODY

text: Areas within General Plans.
label: BODY

text: • From the public, concerns that the City's designation could lead to inflated property
label: BODY

text: values and expectations of landowners to the detriment of agriculture, wildlife
label: BODY

text: habitat, and recreation.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner McGowan and Ms Aramburu met with the Mayor, the City Counsel, and
label: BODY

text: the Planning Director.  At the end of that meeting, Anthony Manzanetti, the City
label: BODY

text: Counsel, agreed to respond to the issues raised by the Commission.  Mr. Manzanetti has
label: BODY

text: prepared a Joint Resolution for consideration for adoption by the Commission and the
label: BODY

text: City to address issues of concern.
label: BODY

text: JOINT RESOLUTION
label: HH1

text: OF THE
label: HH1

text: DELTA PROTECTION COMMISSOIN
label: HH1

text: AND THE
label: HH1

text: CITY OF ELK GROVE
label: HH1

text: WHEREAS, The California State Legislature has declared that the Sacramento-
label: HH1

text: San Joaquin Delta is a natural resource of statewide, national, and
label: BODY

text: international significance, containing irreplaceable resources, and it is the
label: BODY

text: policy of the state to recognize, preserve, and protect those resources of the
label: BODY

text: delta for the use and enjoyment of current and future generations, and
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, The Legislature has created the Delta Protection Commission, and
label: HH1

text: WHEREAS, The mission of the Delta Protection Commission (Commission) is to
label: HH1

text: guide the protection of the Delta's unique natural quality, cultural viability,
label: BODY

text: economic vitality, and recreational opportunity through the protection
label: BODY

text: maintenance, and enhancement and restoration of the overall quality of the
label: BODY

text: Delta environment including agriculture, wildlife habitat, and recreational
label: BODY

text: activities; to assure the orderly, balanced conservation and development of
label: BODY

text: Delta land resources; and to guide the improvement of flood protection to
label: BODY

text: ensure an increased level of public health and safety, and
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS the Commission and the City of Elk Grove share a common goal to
label: HH1

text: implement a comprehensive strategy for the preservation of open space,
label: BODY

text: habitat and agriculture, both inside and outside the City's existing city limits.
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, although not within the current incorporated boundaries of the City
label: HH1

text: of Elk Grove, a portion of the Delta Primary Zone is inside the larger Planning
label: BODY

text: Area of the City’s General Plan, and
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, the City Council of the City of Elk Grove has stated that an
label: HH1

text: important component of the community's vision for the future of Elk Grove is
label: BODY

text: the retention of significant amounts of open space in the Planning Area and has
label: BODY

text: established a policy calling for the creation of a trails system to link the
label: BODY

text: development portions of Elk Grove with these areas, the City, and
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, the City recognizes that there are many important open space
label: HH1

text: resources in the Planning Area, including the Delta and agricultural areas.
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, The City views open space lands of all types as important resources
label: HH1

text: which should be preserved in the region, and supports the establishment of
label: BODY

text: multi-purpose open space areas to address a variety of needs, including, but
label: BODY

text: not limited to: Maintenance of agricultural uses, Wildlife habitat, Recreational
label: BODY

text: open space, Aesthetic benefits, and Flood control,
label: BODY

text: WHEREAS, the City’s general Plan prohibits urbanization within the 100-year
label: HH1

text: Flood Zone and prohibits alteration of the 100-year Flood Zone boundary, and
label: BODY

text: THEREFORE IT IS RESOLVED, that the City's long-term land use policies will
label: HH1

text: require coordination with the Delta Protection Commission if these lands are
label: BODY

text: ever included within the corporate boundary of Elk Grove.
label: BODY

text: IT IS FURTHER RESOLVED, that the City of Elk Grove will coordinate with the
label: HH1

text: Delta Protection Commission by providing updates on the status of any requests
label: BODY

text: by the City to include any lands in the Primary Zone in the City's sphere of
label: BODY

text: influence or incorporated boundaries.
label: BODY

text: IT IS FURTHER RESOLVED, that prior to the annexation of any land in the
label: HH1

text: Primary Zone of the Legal Delta, the City will ensure that its General Plan is
label: BODY

text: consistent with the Delta Protection Commission's Act and Plan as it affects the
label: BODY

text: area within the Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: IT IS FURTHER RESOLVED, that for land within the Primary Zone of the
label: HH1

text: territory of Delta Protection Commission, the City's land use and other policies
label: BODY

text: shall conform with the "Land Use and Resource Management Plan for the
label: BODY

text: Primary Zone of the Delta" developed by the Delta Protection Commission.
label: BODY

text: IT IS FURTHER RESOLVED, that the City and the Commission shall work
label: HH1

text: together with other agencies to develop a regional open space plan which
label: BODY

text: provides for multiple uses of open space, e.g., agriculture and wildlife foraging
label: BODY

text: for those areas within the larger Planning Area of the City’s General Plan Area
label: BODY

text: and the Primary Zones of the territory of the Commission.
label: BODY

text: PASSED AND ADOPTED BY:
label: HH1

text: The City Council of
label: HH1

text: The Delta
label: BODY

text: The City of Elk Grove
label: HH1

text: Protection Commission
label: BODY

text: Daniel Briggs
label: HH1

text: Mike McGowan
label: BODY

text: Mayor of the City of Elk Grove
label: HH1

text: Chair
label: BODY

text: Approved as to form:
label: BODY

text: Approved as to form:
label: BODY

text: Anthony Manzanetti,
label: BODY

text: Daniel L. Siegel,
label: BODY

text: City Attorney
label: BODY

text: Supervising Dep. A.G.
label: BODY

text: Excerpt from May 2004 Minutes
label: HH1

text: Briefing on the City of Elk Grove General Plan and "Planning Area"
label: BODY

text: Chairman McCarty stated that the City of Elk Grove adopted a General Plan and Planning Area
label: BODY

text: for its new city, which includes maps for planning areas and policies outside the city.  He said
label: BODY

text: some of the planning areas include lands that are located in the primary area of the Delta.
label: BODY

text: Ms. Aramburu reported that the new City of Elk Grove, which is located on the edge of the Delta,
label: BODY

text: recently adopted a new general plan.  Currently, the City does not include areas of the Primary
label: BODY

text: Zone, therefore the city is not required to submit its plan for Commission review; however; there
label: BODY

text: are lands located in the Primary Zone which are part of the City’s Planning Area.
label: BODY

text: Mr. Eric Norris, Planning Department of the City of Elk Grove reported that the City is outside
label: BODY

text: the Primary and Secondary Zones; however, it has a Planning Area outside of the City.  He said
label: BODY

text: that the areas on the southern boundary of the City are included in the Secondary Zone; however
label: BODY

text: they are under the jurisdiction of the County of Sacramento.  As of 2002, Elk Grove’s land use
label: BODY

text: policies reflect the County of Sacramento's Land Use Policies.  He said the area is a large flood
label: BODY

text: plain area which is constrained by flooding from the Cosumnes River.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner van Loben Sels asked if the City’s Planning Area extends into The Nature
label: BODY

text: Conservancy lands.  He also asked why the City doesn't pull back from the edge of the Primary
label: BODY

text: Zone with their Planning Area.  Mr. Norris said he did not believe the City extended into TNC
label: BODY

text: areas, but the City of Elk Grove was working cooperatively with The Nature Conservancy with
label: BODY

text: open space issues.  He further stated that when planning the city they used first physical
label: BODY

text: boundaries, however, they did not use the Commission’s boundaries because they felt they would
label: BODY

text: not be moving into the Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: Chairman McCarty asked if the City was respecting the County’s plan, which is part of the
label: BODY

text: Commission’s plan, then why wasn’t the City respecting the Commission’s jurisdictional
label: BODY

text: boundaries.  Mr. Norris responded that those lands were outside of Elk Grove’s jurisdiction;
label: BODY

text: however, if they came into Elk Grove’s jurisdiction those areas would be added to the Elk Grove
label: BODY

text: General Plan, but EG has no intention of going into the Commission’s jurisdiction.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner Curtis stated that it was his understanding that the City of Elk Grove was unable to
label: BODY

text: provide mitigation for some endangered species impacts.  He asked if the City was trying to
label: BODY

text: designate a Sphere of Influence (SOI) as mitigation land for endangered species instead of
label: BODY

text: leaving it under the County’s jurisdiction.  Mr. Norris responded that this was not the case since
label: BODY

text: the land in question was Planning Area land, not sphere of Influence land, which are two different
label: BODY

text: things.   He said that in October 2000, the City went before the Local Agency Formation
label: BODY

text: Commission (LAFCO) for an application for a SOI that included all areas, but worked with the
label: BODY

text: LAFCO to come back with a scaled back application.  However, the only part of the application
label: BODY

text: that went forward was the area of Laguna West.  He said the City has an application on hold with
label: BODY

text: the LAFCO that proposes to include areas close to Grant Line Road (north of Highway 99),
label: BODY

text: which are inside the County's urban service boundary but outside of the Commission's
label: BODY

text: jurisdiction.  Commissioner Curtis stated that the Department of Fish and Game was concerned
label: BODY

text: with the area that overlaps with the Stone Lakes National Wildlife refuge because of the Pacific
label: BODY

text: Flyway and large number of endangered species.  He asked how the City’s Planning Area deals
label: BODY

text: with the area and potential mitigation for current growth of Elk Grove.  Mr. Norris said that the
label: BODY

text: City only addresses the planning areas from a land use perspective and their land use is the same
label: BODY

text: as that of the Sacramento County’s.  He said that they are mitigating the loss of habitat in Elk
label: BODY

text: Grove by collecting increased fees for the Swainson Hawk and the loss of agricultural land, and
label: BODY

text: investigating the purchase of easements through entities like The Nature Conservancy.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner McGowan commented that expansion of a new city usually causes great
label: BODY

text: consternation with the neighbors and the Commission should make responses on the impending
label: BODY

text: fears.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner Coglianese stated that the Commission must come to terms with the fact of
label: BODY

text: extensions of authority of other jurisdiction in the Primary Zone that could lead to urbanization.
label: BODY

text: She asked what the City’s rationale was for entering the Primary Zone with potentially urbanizing
label: BODY

text: change in its Planning Area.  Mr. Norris responded that the Planning Area is not an area the City
label: BODY

text: of Elk Grove wants to include in its SOI now or in the future; nor does it believe the only reason
label: BODY

text: for including an area in a city is to urbanize it.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner McGowan commented that he felt it was wrong and a mistake for the City of Elk
label: BODY

text: Grove to include areas in the Primary Zone in its Planning Area.  He said the Commission should
label: BODY

text: not sit by quietly and allow this to happen and the City should be subject to the Delta Protection
label: BODY

text: Act.  Mr. Norris responded that he understood what was being said and suggested that the
label: BODY

text: Commission have staff write a letter to the Elk Grove City Council to express their concerns.  He
label: BODY

text: said this was not a concern that the Council had heard before; therefore, it could consider revising
label: BODY

text: the map at a future planning cycle to scale back the Planning Area to exclude anything in the
label: BODY

text: Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner Beltran said that the City of Elk Grove was “stirring the pot” with its plan.  He
label: BODY

text: said that a lot of what was happening is a result of cities doing thing like this, without answering
label: BODY

text: the question of "why" they are doing it.  The City of Elk Grove was making it very difficult to be
label: BODY

text: defended when they cannot answer the question as to why they are including land in the Primary
label: BODY

text: Zone in their planning area.  He said that in order to put the Commission at ease, the City of Elk
label: BODY

text: Grove should write a letter to the Commission stating its reasoning for including those lands.  He
label: BODY

text: said they should keep in mind that they are a new city and to think this decision through because
label: BODY

text: what they do affects what happens in other cities, because the Legislature is closely monitoring
label: BODY

text: everything going on in the Primary and Secondary Zones.   He said they should give this area up,
label: BODY

text: or submit Letter of Intent.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner van Loben Sels stated that the Commission should not only send a letter to the
label: BODY

text: City of Elk Grove but also send representatives from RD 744, the Stone Lakes National Wildlife
label: BODY

text: Refuge, the Cosumnes River Preserve and Commission staff to meet with City.  Mr. Norris said
label: BODY

text: the best venue for any discussion would be at the City Council meeting and he would put Ms.
label: BODY

text: Aramburu in touch with the City Clerk to schedule a presentation on the Agenda.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner Cabaldon commented that this would be a simpler issue, but since the City of Elk
label: BODY

text: Grove is not a participant in the Blueprint Project the situation is ambiguous.  He said he felt
label: BODY

text: Commissioner McGowan's assessments were on target.  He said he is concerned, but if it gets to
label: BODY

text: the point of a SOI application then the Commission could block the application.  He said he
label: BODY

text: respected what the City of Elk Grove is trying to do, but some of the messages heard by other
label: BODY

text: cities is not helpful.  He said part of the problem is that Elk Grove is the fastest growing city in
label: BODY

text: the State of California.  He said that sending a constructive letter expressing the Commission’s
label: BODY

text: concerns would help avoid the possibility of a conflict down the road.
label: BODY

text: Chairman McCarty said he agreed with Commissioner's McGowan and Cabaldon.  He said he is
label: BODY

text: concerned because the Commission has seen this before, most recently with the City of Stockton.
label: BODY

text: He also said the City of Elk Grove has an opportunity to take a leadership role and bring reason to
label: BODY

text: the process.  Moreover, the City should recognize that Interstate 5 is a natural barrier that is not
label: BODY

text: going away, the Primary Zone has been designated by the State as "off limits" and the City’s
label: BODY

text: focus should be on the Secondary Zone.
label: BODY

text: Chairman McCarty convened the public hearing.
label: BODY

text: Russell van Loben Sels, Reclamation District 744 trustee, suggested that the expansion of
label: BODY

text: boundaries is not needed.  He said that the City of Elk Grove should be encouraged to adopt the
label: BODY

text: natural boundaries of Interstate 5, and the Stone Lakes Wildlife Refuge.  He said he would be
label: BODY

text: happy to go to the Elk Grove City Council to relay the message.
label: BODY

text: John Bohl, Clarksburg resident, said that the City of Elk Grove is making a mistake as it relates to
label: BODY

text: market value on lands that they may choose to acquire in easements.  He said the perception that
label: BODY

text: they have overlain some boundaries is going to raise the expectations of landowners and raise the
label: BODY

text: costs of the easements.  He referenced a Sacramento Bee article that said that one of the biggest
label: BODY

text: problems in the City of Elk Grove is acquiring affordable mitigation land.  He urged the City to
label: BODY

text: make an amendment to the Planning Area and delete it.
label: BODY

text: Chairman McCarty closed the public hearing
label: BODY

text: It was moved by Commissioner Beltran and seconded by Commission Cabaldon that
label: BODY

text: Commission staff write a letter to the Elk Grove City Council to have a meeting with the
label: BODY

text: Commission for the City to reconsider its inclusion of its planning area within the Primary Zone,
label: BODY

text: and based on that action, follow up that meeting with another meeting between the Commission,
label: BODY

text: the City Council and the Mayor of Elk Grove.   The motion was approved by voice vote.
label: BODY

text: Commissioner van Loben Sels abstained.
label: BODY

text: Commissioners McGowan and Cabaldon volunteered to meet with the City of Elk Grove.
label: BODY

text: Note: The following information was in the May 2004 staff report:
label: HH1

text: CITY BACKGROUND:
label: HH1

text: The City was incorporated in July 2000.  The City adopted its new General Plan on
label: BODY

text: November 19, 2003.
label: BODY

text: LOCATION OF THE CITY OF ELK GROVE:
label: HH1

text: The City limits lie south of the City of Sacramento and north of Kammerer Road.  The
label: BODY

text: City is bounded on the west by I-5 and includes lands east of Highway 99. The City
label: BODY

text: recently annexed the Laguna West area.  The City is east of the Primary Zone of the
label: BODY

text: Delta, however, a very small area along I-5 and north of Elk Grove Boulevard is in the
label: BODY

text: Secondary Zone.
label: BODY

text: REVIEW BY DELTA PROTECTION COMMISSION:
label: HH1

text: The Commission's law requires that local governments ensure that their general plans are
label: BODY

text: consistent with the Commission's regional plan for lands in the Primary Zone.  While
label: BODY

text: the current City of Elk Grove city limits do not include any areas in the Primary Zone, the
label: BODY

text: City's newly adopted General Plan does include and discuss lands in the Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: The General Plan Introduction, p. 5, states:
label: BODY

text: Two-Tiered Planning:  In addition to planning for Elk Grove, this General Plan
label: BODY

text: Addresses a "Planning Area" outside the city limits.  This Planning Area was
label: BODY

text: defined during the process of applying to the Sacramento County Local Agency
label: BODY

text: Formation Committee for a Sphere of Influence; it represents the area which the
label: BODY

text: City envisions may ultimately be included either in a Sphere of Influence or in the
label: BODY

text: incorporated city limits.
label: BODY

text: While the City has no jurisdiction over the determination of land use policy in
label: BODY

text: adjacent areas, it can advise the County on land use policy.  Outside the city
label: BODY

text: limits, therefore, this General Plan is purely advisory, although it does provide a
label: BODY

text: statement of the uses the City desires in these areas.
label: BODY

text: Reflecting the limit of the City's authority to regulate land uses outside its current
label: BODY

text: corporate boundaries, this General Plan provides land use and other policy
label: BODY

text: direction in the following manner:
label: BODY

text: • For the area within the city limits and within the area currently proposed by
label: BODY

text: the City to be included within its Sphere of Influence…this General Plan
label: BODY

text: provides a detailed Land Use Policy Map and other specific policies relating
label: BODY

text: to land use and other issues. (The City in November 2000 applied to the
label: BODY

text: Sacramento County LAFCO for approval of a Sphere of Influence which
label: BODY

text: includes these areas…)
label: BODY

text: • For the area outside the city limits, this General Plan provides land use
label: BODY

text: designations at a more conceptual level; because the City does not have land
label: BODY

text: use authority in these areas, detailed land use categories have not been
label: BODY

text: assigned, and the policies of this General Plan with regard to other issues
label: BODY

text: (Circulation, housing, noise, etc.) are advisory only and are intended to be
label: BODY

text: considered by the County of Sacramento in its review and approval of
label: BODY

text: development projects and other matters in this larger "planning area".
label: BODY

text: PROCESS IF THE CITY ADDS LANDS IN THE PRIMARY ZONE TO THE
label: HH1

text: CITY LIMITS:
label: HH1

text: As discussed previously, if the City does incorporate lands in the Primary Zone in the city
label: BODY

text: limits, the City will have to submit its General Plan to the Commission for review and a
label: BODY

text: determination of consistency.  When the Commission reviews a local government
label: BODY

text: General Plan, the Commission must approve the local general plan by a majority vote of
label: BODY

text: the Commission membership (ten votes) after making all of the following written
label: BODY

text: findings regarding the general plan and any development approved or proposed that is
label: BODY

text: consistent with the General Plan (Public Resources Code, Section 29763.5):
label: BODY

text: • Consistent with the regional plan (Land Use and Resource Management Plan for the
label: BODY

text: Primary Zone of the Delta).
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in wetland or riparian loss.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in the degradation of water quality.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in increased nonpoint source pollution.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in the degradation or reduction of Pacific Flyway habitat.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in reduced public access, provided the access does not infringe on
label: BODY

text: private property rights.
label: BODY

text: • Will not expose the public to increased flood hazard.
label: BODY

text: • Will not adversely impact agricultural lands or increase the potential for vandalism,
label: BODY

text: trespass, or the creation of public or private nuisances on public or private land.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in the degradation or impairment of levee integrity.
label: BODY

text: • Will not adversely impact navigation.
label: BODY

text: • Will not result in any increased requirements or restrictions upon agricultural
label: BODY

text: practices in the Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: DESCRIPTION OF THE CITY OF ELK GROVE:
label: HH1

text: The City of Elk Grove's planning area includes 93,560 acres in southern Sacramento
label: BODY

text: County.  The City limits include 26,910 acres (42 square miles); this includes the area
label: BODY

text: known as Laguna West that was recently annexed into the City.  The City and planning
label: BODY

text: area are bounded by the Stone Lakes National Wildlife Refuge and the Sacramento River
label: BODY

text: to the west, the Cities of Sacramento and Rancho Cordova to the north and the Cosumnes
label: BODY

text: River to the south east.  Within the larger planning area lie the unincorporated
label: BODY

text: community of Hood, to the west, and the area known as Point Pleasant, to the south.  The
label: BODY

text: City has two major north-south freeways--I-5 and 99.  Several large east-west
label: BODY

text: expressways connect these two highways.
label: BODY

text: DESCRIPTION OF PRIMARY ZONE LANDS WITHIN THE CITY LIMITS:
label: HH1

text: There are no lands in the existing city limits in the Primary Zone.  However, substantial
label: BODY

text: lands west of I-5, south of the City of Sacramento and north of Twin Cities Road are
label: BODY

text: identified as "Planning Area" and included on maps in the City's General Plan.
label: BODY

text: The Elk Grove General Plan Glossary (p. 188) defines Planning Area as "the area directly
label: BODY

text: addressed by the general plan.  A city's planning areas typically encompasses the city
label: BODY

text: limits and potentially annexable land within its sphere of influence."
label: BODY

text: CURRENT GENERAL PLAN DESIGNATIONS (SACRAMENTO COUNTY):
label: HH1

text: Lands west of I-5 are located in Sacramento County.  The General Plan designation is
label: BODY

text: "Agricultural Cropland".
label: BODY

text: CURRENT ZONING (SACRAMENTO COUNTY):
label: HH1

text: Lands lying west of I-5, and bounded by Elliott Ranch Road and Hood Franklin Road are
label: BODY

text: zoned RR(F), Recreation Reserve, with Flood overlay.  Other lands to the north and south
label: BODY

text: of the RR area, and west of I-5 are zoned AG-80(F), Agriculture with 80 acre minimum
label: BODY

text: parcel with Flood overlay.
label: BODY

text: CITY OF ELK GROVE GENERAL PLAN DESIGNATIONS:
label: HH1

text: The Planning Area Land Use Concept Map (attached) identifies the lands west of I-5 as
label: BODY

text: "Open Space Reserve and Limited Development--Constrained by flooding."
label: BODY

text: CITY OF ELK GROVE ZONING:
label: HH1

text: As the lands in the Planning Area are not in the City limits, the City has not adopted any
label: BODY

text: zoning for lands in the "Planning Area".
label: BODY

text: CITY OF ELK GROVE GENERAL PLAN POLICIES REGARDING THE
label: HH1

text: PRIMARY ZONE OF THE DELTA:
label: HH1

text: (Note: Text in italic is quoted from the City of Elk Grove General Plan)
label: BODY

text: CONSERVATION AND AIR QUALITY ELEMENT:
label: HH1

text: Sacramento River Delta (page 43):
label: HH1

text: Although not within the current incorporated boundaries of Elk Grove, a portion of the
label: BODY

text: Sacramento River Delta is inside the larger Planning Area of the General
label: BODY

text: Plan…Therefore, the City's long-term land use policies will require coordination with the
label: BODY

text: Delta Protection Commission (a state agency) once these lands are included within the
label: BODY

text: corporate boundary of Elk Grove.
label: BODY

text: Mission Statement:
label: BODY

text: The mission of the Commission is to guide the protection of the Delta's unique natural
label: BODY

text: quality, cultural viability, economic vitality, and recreational opportunity through:
label: BODY

text: • Protection maintenance, and enhancement and restoration of the overall quality of
label: BODY

text: the Delta environment including agriculture, wildlife habitat, and recreational
label: BODY

text: activities;
label: BODY

text: • Assurance of orderly, balanced conservation and development of Delta land
label: BODY

text: resources;
label: BODY

text: • Improvement of flood protection to ensure an increased level of public health and
label: BODY

text: safety.
label: BODY

text: Vision Statement:
label: BODY

text: The vision of the Delta Protection Commission is a region in which the essential land
label: BODY

text: uses and unique natural qualities flourish in self-sustaining harmony.
label: BODY

text: Conservation Policies: Conservation of Agricultural Uses:
label: HH1

text: CAQ-3: The City of Elk Grove considers the only mitigation for the loss of agricultural
label: HH1

text: land to consist of the creation of new agricultural land in the Sacramento region equal in
label: BODY

text: area, productivity, and other characteristics to the area which would be lost due to
label: BODY

text: development.  The protection of existing agricultural land through the purchase of fee
label: BODY

text: title of easements is not considered by the City to provide mitigation since programs of
label: BODY

text: this type result in a net loss of farmland.
label: BODY

text: CAQ-4: While agricultural uses are anticipated to be phased out within the city limits,
label: HH1

text: the City recognizes the right of these uses to continue as long as individual
label: BODY

text: owners/farmers desire.  The City shall not require buffers between farmland and urban
label: BODY

text: uses, relying instead on the following actions to address the impacts of farming on urban
label: BODY

text: uses:
label: BODY

text: Action 1: Implement the City "Right to Farm" Ordinance.
label: BODY

text: Action 2: Prospective buyers of property adjacent to agricultural land shall be notified
label: BODY

text: through the title report that they could be subject to inconvenience or discomfort
label: BODY

text: resulting from accepted farming activities as per provisions of the City's right-to-farm
label: BODY

text: ordinance.
label: BODY

text: Conservation Policies: Land within the Primary Zone of the Sacramento River Delta:
label: HH1

text: CAQ-6: Within the Primary Zone of the Legal Delta…the City's land use and other
label: HH1

text: policies shall conform with the "Land Use and Resource Management Plan for the
label: BODY

text: Primary Zone of the Delta" developed by the Delta Protection Commission.
label: BODY

text: Action 1: Coordinate with the Delta Protection Commission by providing updates on the
label: BODY

text: status of any requests by the City to include any lands in the Primary Zone in the City's
label: BODY

text: sphere of influence or incorporated boundaries.
label: BODY

text: Action 2: Prior to the annexation of any land in the Primary Zone of the Legal Delta,
label: BODY

text: ensure that this General Plan is consistent with the Delta Protection Commission's Act
label: BODY

text: and Plan as it affects the area within the Primary Zone.
label: BODY

text: LAND USE ELEMENT:
label: HH1

text: Sphere of Influence and Annexation (page 122):
label: HH1

text: This General Plan provides land use planning for the City and a larger Planning Area.
label: BODY

text: The Planning Area is intended to be an area in which the City has an interest in guiding
label: BODY

text: land use decisions by the County of Sacramento, and is envisioned as the area into which
label: BODY

text: the incorporated city boundaries may eventually expand.
label: BODY

text: Land Use Policies: Areas Outside the Incorporated Area of Elk Grove:
label: HH1

text: LU-12: The Land Use Policy Map of the Planning Area (Figure LU-2) provides
label: HH1

text: conceptual land use policy for the area outside the current incorporated boundaries of
label: BODY

text: Elk Grove.  This policy is intended as a statement of the City's long-term vision for this
label: BODY

text: area; these lands remain under the jurisdiction of Sacramento County.  Except where
label: BODY

text: specifically indicated, the City's land use policy for areas outside the city limits reflects
label: BODY

text: the County of Sacramento's land use policy as it existed on December 31, 2002.
label: BODY

text: Land Use Policies: Urban Study Areas
label: HH1

text: LU-17: Implement a comprehensive and city-wide strategy for the preservation of open
label: HH1

text: space, habitat and agriculture, both inside and outside the City's existing city limits.
label: BODY

text: Action 1: Within 90 days of the adoption of this General Plan, staff shall bring to the City
label: BODY

text: Council for its consideration options available for the strategic funding, acquisition and
label: BODY

text: management of land in and proximate to the City for the purposes of preserving open
label: BODY

text: space, habitat and agriculture.
label: BODY

text: PARKS, TRAILS AND OPEN SPACE ELEMENT:
label: HH1

text: Trails and Open Space (p. 149): An important component of the community's vision for
label: HH1

text: the future of Elk Grove is the retention of significant amounts of open space in the
label: BODY

text: Planning Area…and the creation of a trails system to link the development portions of
label: BODY

text: Elk Grove with these areas…the City recognizes that there are many important open
label: BODY

text: space resources in the Planning Area, including…the Delta and agricultural areas.
label: BODY

text: PTO-15: The City views open space lands of all types as important resource which
label: HH1

text: should be preserved in the region, and supports the establishment of multi-purpose open
label: BODY

text: space areas to address a variety of needs, including, but not limited to:
label: BODY

text: • Maintenance of agricultural uses
label: BODY

text: • Wildlife habitat
label: BODY

text: • Recreational open space
label: BODY

text: • Aesthetic benefits
label: BODY

text: • Flood control
label: BODY

text: To the extent possible, lands protected in accordance with this policy should be in
label: BODY

text: proximity to Elk Grove, to facilitate use of these areas by Elk Grove residents, assist in
label: BODY

text: mitigation of habitat loss within the City, and provide an open space resource close to the
label: BODY

text: urbanized areas of Elk Grove.
label: BODY

text: Action 1: Consider the establishment of a citywide fee and/or assessment system which
label: HH1

text: would provide funding for the purchase of open space land or easements and the
label: BODY

text: maintenance of these areas.
label: BODY

text: Action 2: Work with the County of Sacramento and other resource agencies to develop a
label: HH1

text: regional open space plan which provides for multiple uses of open space (e.g. agriculture
label: BODY

text: and wildlife foraging).
label: BODY

text: Action 3: Consider using funds collected under existing (2003) fee programs (e.g.
label: HH1

text: Swainson's Hawk mitigation and East Franklin Specific Plan agricultural mitigation) to
label: BODY

text: fund this expanded open space program.
label: BODY

text: SAFETY ELEMENT
label: HH1

text: Drainage and Flooding (p. 173):
label: HH1

text: SA-13: The City shall require that all new projects not result in new or increased
label: HH1

text: flooding impacts on adjoining parcels on upstream and downstream areas.
label: BODY

text: SA-15: Development shall not be permitted on land subject to flooding during a 100-year
label: HH1

text: event, based on the most recent floodplain mapping prepared by the Federal Emergency
label: BODY

text: management Agency (FEMA) or updated mapping acceptable to the City of Elk Grove…
label: BODY

text: SA 16: A buildable area outside the 100-year floodplain must be present on every
label: HH1

text: residential lot sufficient to accommodate a residence and associated structures.  Fill may
label: BODY

text: be placed to create a buildable area only if approved by the City and in accordance with
label: BODY

text: all other applicable policies and regulations.  The use of fill in the 100-year floodplain to
label: BODY

text: create buildable area is strongly discouraged, and shall be subject to review to determine
label: BODY

text: potential impacts on wildlife, habitat, and flooding on other parcels.
label: BODY
